educational_objective: Identify first-degree atrioventricular block on ECG.
question_text: A 51-year-old man is evaluated for syncope after prolonged standing in a warm environment.ECG is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following ECG abnormalities is shown?
critique: First-degree atrioventricular block (Option A) is shown on this patient's ECG. First-degree atrioventricular block, which is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>200 ms or >5 small boxes on an ECG), is usually a benign condition and does not require intervention. It is most commonly secondary to use of medications that slow atrioventricular node conduction; degeneration of the node; infiltrative cardiomyopathies; or, as in this case, high vagal tone.
